string.text:
This is the sawn off version of the popular Toz-34 hunting rifle. Nothing much to say about it, keep it clean, and it will save your life many times...

 Ammunition:
 12x70 buckshot
A standard round .45 caliber round. It has a standard lead core and is a full-jacketed bullet.
A 'Shock' .45 caliber round with improved characteristics. A hollow-point bullet with good stopping power.
A standard 12 caliber round filled with 6mm buckshot. Has good stopping power at a close range. Most effective at ranges under 30 meters.
A finned bullet. Stabilizes in flight, which greatly increases its accuracy. Has an armor-piercing effect and an increased range. Effective at a range of up to approx. 80-100 meters.

A round with a heavy, naked bullet. Mostly used for big game hunting, but can be used for other purposes. Its heavy bullet does not pierce, but forces itself through bulletproof vests. Effective range is up to approx. 50-70 meters.
An armor-piercing round for the AK-74, the AK-74SU and the AN-94 "Abakan" assault rifles. Has an improved armor-piercing effect, but decreased stopping power.
A standard round for the AK-74, the AK-74SU, and the AN-94 "Abakan" assault rifles. Has a standard core and a full-jacketed bullet.
An armor-piercing bullet for most NATO weapons.
A standard NATO round widely-known under its Belgian SS109 index.

A standard surplus round with steel casing for the Mosin Nagant. Cheap production methods, and corrosive primers result in more fouling of the gun, and a small decrease in ballistics. Not suited for the the Dragunov SVD, and SVU sniper rifles.
A sniper round for the Mosin Nagant, the Dragunov SVD, and SVU sniper rifles. Has an improved accuracy and range.
A sniper round with an armor-piercing tip, for the Mosin Nagant, the Dragunov SVD, and SVU sniper rifles.
A standard round for the Makarov PM, PB 6P9, and Fort 12 pistols. Has a standard core and full-jacketed bullet with a weak armor-piercing effect.

A round with improved ballistic characteristics for the Makarov PM, PB 6P9, and Fort 12 pistols. More effective than a standard round due to the high initial velocity of the bullet. Has a higher armor-piercing effect.
A standard 9x19mm round. Has a full-jacketed bullet with a weak armor-piercing effect.
An improved round for weapons chambered for 9x19mm. A high-powered round with a hollow-point bullet and an armor-piercing core.

An armor-piercing round for the Groza OC-14, the AS Val, SR-3 "Vikhr", and the VSS Vintorez sniper rifle. It has a subsonic bullet which, due to its special design, can penetrate most bulletproof vests at a range of up to 400 meters.

A round for the Groza OC-14, the AS Val, SR-3 "Vikhr". This is a cheaper modification of the armor-piercing round, is not quite as good in quality, as the other 9x39mm ammo. Cheap production methods result in more fouling of the gun, and a decrease in ballistics. Not suited for the VSS Vintorez sniper rifle, due to the decreased ballistics.

A sniper round for the Groza OC-14, the AS Val, SR-3 "Vikhr", and the VSS Vintorez sniper rifle. It has a subsonic bullet which due to its heavy weight and special design can penetrate most bulletproof vests at a range of up to 400 meters.
Energy cells prepared with lethal elements in a rifle magazine. The energy source is an encapsulated piece of the Flash Artifact.
A 40mm grenade, the M406 High-Explosive Round, for the M203 grenade launcher, and the integrated grenade launcher of the FN F2000.
A highly-explosive 40mm fragmentation warhead for the RPG-7. Equally effective against troops and light armored vehicles.
A 40mm grenade for the GP-25 Kastyor grenade launcher, the Groza OC-14's integrated grenade launcher, and the RG-6 revolver grenade launcher.

A 40mm grenade for the GP-25 Kastyor grenade launcher, the Groza OC-14's integrated grenade launcher, and the RG-6 revolver grenade launcher. Prior to explosion, the grenade leaps in to the air about one meter, increasing its kill effectiveness.
A defensive hand grenade with a large radius of shrapnel damage. It is recommended to throw it from behind cover.
A smoke grenade. Creates a smoke screen for cover. Lasts for 10 seconds.
An offensive hand grenade with a small radius of shrapnel damage.

The weapon of the elite troops in the Russian Army. Designed as a replacement for the outdated AK-74. The Abakan’s receiver and barrel are movable, which helps decrease recoil and increase accuracy. Due to the special design of the muzzle break the rifle can not be fitted with a silencer. 

 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.45x39mm
 Armor-Piercing 5.45x39mm BP
A modified AN-94 fitted with an optic sight for carrying out sniper fire. The optics embedded into the body of the weapon has a higher resolution than the standard model.
A modified AN-94 fitted with an integrated granade launcher under the barrel, making it an even more versatile weapon.
A grenade launcher for the AK-74 and AK-103.\n Ammunition:\n VOG-25 and VOG-25P grenades

A grenade launcher that will fit most NATO weapons.

 Ammunition:
 M203 grenades
A widely used Soviet scope. The scope can be mounted on a weapon using a dovetail mount used by the Warsaw Pact countries.
A 4X scope produced in the NATO countries. It can be attached to a standard Picatinny Rail.
A 4X scope for the MP5SD. It can be attached to the proprietary Picatinny Rail on the MP5SD3.
A 4X scope produced in the NATO countries for the H&K G3. It can be attached to a standard Picatinny Rail.
An effective silencer made by Zone gunsmiths. The kit includes a set of adapters for most weapons.

A 1974 model assault rifle. A simple and reliable weapon, but its production quality affects the gun's ergonomics and accuracy. The main weapon of choice for Stalkers and "lone wolves".

 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.45x39mm
 Armor-Piercing 5.45x39mm BP
An enhanced variant of the AK-74, fitted with a modified closing system that increases the rifle's rate of fire.

The weight and size of the AK-74SU are similar to those of a Submachine Gun, but its mode of operation and the ammunition type it uses place it into the class of Assault Rifles. Its small dimensions are very useful when fighting inside a building or within a thick forest, and has relatively high piercing capabilities. Its main disadvantages are a limited accuracy range and quick overheating when firing bursts. This version is fitted with an extended 40 round magazine.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.45x39mm
 Armor-Piercing 5.45x39mm BP
An enhanced variant of the AK-74SU. Fitted with a non-removable silencer.

Adopted by the American army and police, as well as many military and police units all over the world. It is especially popular among criminals for its high-powered rounds and high-capacity magazine.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x19mm FMJ
 Improved 9x19mm PB1s

A double-barreled shotgun with a shortened barrel. Lighter and more compact, but is only effective at close range. A weapon most commonly used by rookies. Often used as a sidearm for CQB.

 Ammunition:
 16x70 buckshot
A silenced variant of the Colt M1911 pistol - the weapon of choice by hired assassins. Fitted with a non-removable silencer.

A great, reliable pistol. Uses a small-size magazine which is balanced by the use of high-powered rounds.

 Ammunition:
 Standard .45 ACP
 Improved .45 ACP Shock

Big, heavy, loud, and very destructive. Not very popular in the Zone due to its price and size. Besides, there aren't any elephants to hunt down around here!

 Ammunition:
 Standard .45 ACP
 Improved .45 ACP Shock
A variant of the Desert Eagle. Originally the .50AE caliber version, but it has been converted to use the 9x39mm rifle rounds. A devastating killing machine in Close Quarters Combat.

A modern bullpup assault rifle, equipped with an electronic fire control module and a 40-mm grenade launcher.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.56x45mm SS109
 Armor-Piercing 5.56x45mm AP

A pistol produced for the Ukrainian police force, which replaced the PM. Improved accuracy, ergonomics, and a larger magazine.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x18mm
 Improved 9x18mm +P+
An experimental prototype of the Fort 12 pistol, designed to be its successor.

An assault rifle manufactured by Heckler and Koch in Germany. A first-grade specimen of modern weaponry: light, reliable, and ergonomic.
 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.56x45mm SS109
 Armor-Piercing 5.56x45mm AP

A super-accurate weapon made in secrecy by Agroprom Research Institute scientists, in co-operation with the Testing Workshop in Zaton. Gunfire is nearly inaudible, due to its use of energy obtained "Flash" artifacts instead of gunpowder. In spite of the Flash Rifle’s tremendous firepower, the recoil is insignificant. The accuracy and power of this gun exceeds those of all other small arms.\n\n Ammunition: 2mm Flash rounds

An assault rifle with an attached grenade launcher. An ideal assault rifle for Zone conditions: compact, reliable, versatile, and powerful. A favorite among many Stalkers.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x39 PAB9
 Armor-Piercing 9x39 AP
 Sniper 9x39 SP5
 VOG-25 and VOG-25P grenades
A Groza OC-14 with a modified barrel, which allows the rifle to utilize the more available 5.45x39mm round.

Considered as one of the best pistols of the 20th century. Reliable, powerful, and good accuracy. Magazine can hold 13 rounds.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x19mm FMJ
 Improved 9x19mm PB1s
A sharp, clip-point, stainless steel hunting knife.

During the British Army's engagement in Afghanistan, the L85A1 began appearing on the black market in Eastern Europe, and eventually found it's way into The Zone in small numbers. The L85A1’s main advantage is a standard 4X scope. Highly accurate, but decreases in Burst fire mode. Internal mechanisms of the A1 model, however, are not always reliable, and are prone to jamming if the rifle is not properly maintained.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.56x45mm SS109
 Armor-Piercing 5.56x45mm AP
A modified Enfield L85A1 with diminished recoil using weights.
A modified Enfield L85A1 with an integrated silencer. Many parts were replaced with lighter components, making the weapon significantly lighter.

A light rifle with an effective fire range of up to 300 meters. Great ergonomics and lightweight, this weapon is highly accurate. However, it is sensitive to dirt and is not ideal for difficult field conditions.
 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.56x45mm SS109
 Armor-Piercing 5.56x45mm AP

A modified LR-300ML capable of firing single shots, and 3 round bursts. Geared to be used as a cheap alternative to a sniper rifle. Scope and silencer are permanently fixed to the receiver, and barrel, to increase accuracy.

One of the best weapons in the Submachine Gun class. It was adopted by armies and special forces units in many countries. When it was gradually replaced with more up-to-date models, it began to appear on the black market and numerous weapons found their way to the Zone.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x19mm FMJ
 Improved 9x19mm PB1s
A H&K MP5A5 submachine gun modified to utilize the 9x18mm round. A great, reliable submachine gun.
A H&K MP5A5 submachine gun fitted with a non-removeable silencer.

A pistol with an integrated silencer and used by Soviet special forces. An outdated weapon, but is still very effective in skillful hands.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x18mm
 Improved 9x18mm +P+

The most widespread pistol in the Zone; a legacy of the Soviet era. Relatively reliable and cheap, it has a low magazine capacity, low power, and mediocre accuracy. The main weapon of many rookie Stalkers.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x18mm
 Improved 9x18mm +P+

A revolver-type 40mm grenade launcher. An indispensable weapon, particularly when targeting large numbers of mutants, attacking well-guarded stationary objects, or fighting especially tough creatures.\n\n Ammunition: VOG-25 and VOG-25P grenades
A modified variant of the revolving grenade launcher, converted to use M203 grenades.

A rocket-propelled grenade launcher, developed in the 1960s. RPGs are stored in large quantities in army depots, from where they are transferred to the Zone. Such weapons are rarely used by Stalkers: its huge dimensions and heavy weight make it unpopular, though it can be an indispensable weapon for certain missions.\n Ammunition: OG-7V warheads

An lightweight assault rifle geared for urban warfare. To lighten its weight, some parts were removed and/or replaced. As a result, there are no rails to attach a sight, silencer, or a grenade launcher to the rifle.

A SIG SG-550 modified for sniper fire. Fitted with a non-removeable optical sight, with a high magnification. Rifle has been modified to shoot single shots, and 2 rounds bursts, a higher fire rate increases the hit probability of both rounds hitting their target in 2 round burst mode. It does not accept a grenade launcher or silencer, as this would disturb the barrel harmonics, decreasing accuracy.

A pistol developed in 1975, yet is still popular around the world. Has a low capacity magazine, but is extremely reliable and uses the high-powered .45 ACP round.

 Ammunition:
 Standard .45 ACP
 Improved .45 ACP Shock

A relatively new assault rifle utilizing the 5.56x45mm SS109 round. This weapon is very popular due to its accuracy, soft recoil, and high reliability.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.56x45mm SS109
 Armor-Piercing 5.56x45mm AP

The SPAS-12 is a smooth-bore shotgun that was developed in the late 1970s. This weapon is very reliable and relatively popular. However, it is large, expensive, and contains very complex mechanisms. An ideal weapon for Close Quarters Combat.
 Ammunition:
 12x70 buckshot
 12x76 slug
 12x76 dart

A uniquely modified SPAS-12 shotgun, which has a threaded bore that greatly increases its accuracy. Fires only slugs and darts, since regular buckshot will damage the threaded barrel.

 Ammunition:
 12x76 slug
 12x76 dart

Widely used in all operations of the Soviet and Russian armies since the 1960s. Proved to be an exceptionally reliable and handy weapon. Sniper rifle of choice by the experienced Stalkers of the "Duty" faction.

 Ammunition:
Armor-Piercing 7.62x54mm BP
 Sniper 7.62x54mm 7N14
A modified Dragunov SVD sniper rifle with improved optics, allowing the user to zoom in further. The rifle's weight is balanced, resulting in decreased recoil.

An updated variant of the Dragunov SVD sniper rifle. A compact bullpup model, which is excellent for long treks into the Zone. Can fire automatically for CQB operations.

 Ammunition:
Armor-Piercing 7.62x54mm BP
 Sniper 7.62x54mm 7N14

A regular double-barreled shotgun in the over/under configuration, simple to use, and powerful. Good for hunting mutants, and regular game.

 Ammunition:
 12x70 buckshot
 12x76 slug
 12x76 dart

A very reliable pistol. A high-quality, compact, close-range weapon, it is very popular among the Zone veterans.

 Ammunition:
 Standard .45 ACP
 Improved .45 ACP Shock

This weapon is based on the VSS Vintorez sniper rifle. It has a folding stock, and has a larger magazine capacity than the VSS Vintorez. Originally designed for special forces units operating in conditions demanding silenced and high powered fire.
 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x39mm PAB-9
 Armor-Piercing 9x39mm SP-6
 Sniper 9x39mm SP-5

A modified AS Val rifle that has a high quality, non-removable optical sight mounted. To ensure accuracy, and reliability of this customized rifle, it only fires SP-6, and SP-5 rounds.

 Ammunition:
Armor-Piercing 9x39mm SP-6
 Sniper 9x39mm SP-5

A special sniper rifle designed for silenced sniper fire. Equipped with an integrated silencer and can pierce any bulletproof vest at a range of up to 400 meters. Highly valued by Stalkers of any level. Since the VSS is meant for use in discreet operations, the VSS can be broken down into three parts to be carried in a special 450 x 370 x 140 mm briefcase.

 Ammunition:
Armor-Piercing 9x39mm SP-6
 Sniper 9x39mm SP-5

An excellent pistol. A highly accurate and reliable gun with a high capacity magazine.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 9x19mm FMJ
 Improved 9x19mm PB1s
A modified Walther P99 that utilizes 9x18mm rounds.

A very reliable, smooth-bore, pump-action shotgun made for use in hostile environments.

 Ammunition:
 12x70 buckshot
 12x76 slug
 12x76 dart

BM16 double-barreled shotgun in the side by side configuration. Simple, reliable, good for hunting mutants, and regular wildlife. Though not as powerful as the TOZ-34.
 Ammunition:
 16x70 buckshot
 16x70 slug
 16x70 dart

The Kalashnikov assault rifle, model 1947. A simple and reliable weapon, but its production quality affects the gun's ergonomics and accuracy. It is a sought after weapon in The Zone due to it's higher stopping power compared to the AK-74.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 7.62x39mm
 Armor-Piercing 7.62x39mm BP.
An armor-piercing round for the AK-47, and the AK-103 assault rifles. Has an improved armor-piercing effect, but decreased stopping power.
A standard round for the AK-47, and the AK-103 assault rifles. Has a standard lead core and is a full-jacketed bullet.

Semi-automatic Smooth-Bore carbine Saiga-12C. The given firearm is the civilian variant of the Saiga-12 series carbines, used for sport-shooting and hunting. Tactical models such as the Saiga-12K exist, which are used in close-quarters combat situations by police and special forces. A very deadly and accurate weapon.

 Ammunition:
 12õ70 Shot,
 12x76 Slug,
 12x76 Dart.

The PPSh-41 (Pistolet-Pulemyot Shpagina, nicknamed Pah-Pah-sha) submachine gun was one of the most mass produced weapons of its type of World War II. It was designed by Georgi Shpagin, as an inexpensive alternative to the PPD-40, which was expensive and time consuming to build. The PPSh had a simple blow-back action and a box or drum magazine. It was made with metal stampings to ease production, and its chrome-lined chamber and bore helped to make the gun very low-maintenance in combat settings.

 Ammunition:
 7.62x25mm P
 7.62x25mm PS
The 7.62x25P cartridge is a bottle-necked pistol cartridge widely used in former Soviet and Soviet satellite states, so it is possible to find them in the Zone too. They are for PPSh-41.

The 7.62x25PS cartridge is a bottle-necked pistol cartridge widely used in former Soviet and Soviet satellite states, so it is possible to find them in the Zone too. They are for PPSh-41. The "PS" version makes more damage, than the normal "P" version, due to a heavier bullet, and higher bullet velocity.
Variation of the Winchester. A small fragment of the artifact "Gravi" was built into the barrel, positioned in such a way as to increase the speed of the bullet's flight.

The P90 is a Belgian personal defense weapon developed between 1986-1987 at Fabrique Nationale de Herstal. The weapon’s name is an abbreviation of Project, and the number 90 specifies a weapon system of the 1990s.

 Ammunition:
 5.7x28mm SS190 
 5.7x28mm AP
A standard NATO round widely-known under its Belgian SS109 index. Used with the FN P90 assault rifles. Standard lead core, FMJ bullet
A round with an armor-piercing bullet for the FN P90 assault rifles.

The PKM is a general purpose machine gun designed in the Soviet Union. The PKM machine gun was introduced in the 1960s and replaced the SGM and RPD machine guns in Soviet service. PKM can be used as a light anti-aircraft weapon when it is put on an AA mount. One feature typical to Soviet machine guns is that the standard model feeds from the right and ejects its rounds via an ejection port on the left side of the weapon, as opposed to the usual right side ejection port seen in most western machine guns.

 Ammunition:
 7.62mm x 54R Box
7.62mm x 54R ammunition for PKM machine guns.

The Kriss Super V submachine gun is an interesting experimental weapon, its name Kriss comes from Indonesian sword or large knife with flame-like blade. This weapon is intended to provide operators with improved control over accuracy and bullet dispersion, in both semi-automatic and full automatic modes, while firing hard-hitting .45 ACP ammunition. The overall design also permits the Kriss to be fired single-handed when required by tactical situations and with adequate accuracy.
 Ammunition:
 .45 ACP, 
 .45ACP Shock.

The MP7A3 is a German submachine gun manufactured by Heckler & Koch (H&K), this version is chambered for the 5.7x28mm cartridge. It was designed to meet NATO requirements published in 1989 calling for a personal defense weapon (PDW) class firearm with a greater ability to defeat body armor than current weapons, which are limited due to the use of conventional pistol cartridges.
 Ammunition:
 5.7x28mm SS190 
 5.7x28mm AP.

The Bizon uses a helical magazine, similar to the type used in the American Calico 960 submachine gun. The 64-round magazine mounts under the foregrip positioned in line with the barrel. This layout makes the weapon more compact and concealable. Magazines on some earlier models incorporate an ammunition counter to show how many rounds remain. The Bizon is primarily intended for counter-terrorist and law enforcement units that usually need fast and accurate fire at closer ranges. The Bizon was developed by Viktor Kalashnikov, the son of legendary AK-47 designer Mikhail Kalashnikov.
 Ammunition:
 9x18mm 
 9x18mm +P+.

The Steyr TMP (Tactical Machine Pistol) is a select-fire 9x19mm Parabellum caliber machine pistol manufactured by the Austrian company, Steyr Mannlicher. It is renowned for its controllability, allowing a shooter to accurately fire the gun in bursts of up to 15 or 30 (the full magazine size), instead of the typical 3-shot or 2-shot bursts that other submachine guns are limited to. 
 Ammunition:
 9x19mm FMJ 
 9x19mm BP1.

The MAC-10 (Military Armament Corporation Model 10) is a highly compact, blowback operated, selective fire submachine gun (technically, a machine pistol) developed by Gordon B. Ingram in 1964. It is a simple, low-cost design with few moving parts, making it easy to manufacture and maintain. A favorite among bandits. 
 Ammunition:
 9x19mm FMJ 
 9x19mm BP1.

The Interdynamic KG-9, also called as Intratec TEC-9 is a blowback-operated, semi-automatic 9x19mm Parabellum caliber firearm, classified by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, and Firearms as a handgun. It is made of inexpensive molded polymer and stamped steel parts. Magazine holds 32 rounds. Often modified by criminals to fire in full auto.
 Ammunition:
 9x19mm FMJ 
 9x19mm BP1.

The OTs-33 Pernach is a Russian machine pistol, derived from the APS Stechkin. The Pernach (Russian: multivaned mace) is an automatic (machine) pistols designed to replace the obsolete APS pistols in various special OMON units in Russian police and other paramilitary units. It was developed in 1995 by Igor Stechkin at the TsKIB SOO company, and it went into limited production by the KBP Instrument Design Bureau.
 Ammunition:
 9x18mm 
 9x18mm +P+.

The Benelli M3 (Super 90) is a pump-action or semi-automatic shotgun designed and manufactured by Italian firearms manufacturer Benelli. The M3 holds a maximum of five rounds, and uses the proprietary Benelli semi-automatic system first showcased in the M1. The M3 is notable for allowing the user the choice of semi-automatic or pump-action operation. It is reliable and versatile, and well loved by both police forces and civilian sportsmen.
 Ammunition:
 12x70 buckshot
 12x76 slug
 12x76 dart.

Small automatic SR-3 "Vikhr" was developed on the basis of the AS-VAL, for Special Forces units. The SR-3 is a very small size weapon, comparable to the size of small submachineguns, but clearly superior to their firepower through the use of special armour cartridges SP-6, SP-5, and PAB-9 (9x39mm). Unlike the AS-VAL, SR-3 does not have a silencer, and the barrel does not support mounting of a silencer.\ N Ammunition: \ n 9x39mm PAB-9, \ n 9x39 mm armour-SP-6, \ n sniper 9x39mm SP-5.

The AK-103 is a modern Russian-built version of the famous AK-47 assault rifle, chambered for the 7.62x39mm M43 round. It combines the developments made in the AK-74 and AK-101 with a use of plastics to replace metal or wooden components wherever possible to reduce overall weight. The AK-103 can be fitted with a tactical light, laser sight, telescopic sight, suppressor, and the GP-25 grenade launcher. The AK-103 is in limited service with selected units in the Russian army, and is already being exported to other countries such as Venezuela.\n Ammo:\ 7.62x39mm (All Types)

In 1976 a shortened version of the MP5A2 was introduced, the MP5K (K – Kurz), designed with clandestine operations and special services in mind primarily for close quarters battle. This SMG does not have a shoulder stock (the receiver end was covered with a flat cover), and the bolt and receiver were shortened at the rear. The resultant lighter bolt led to a higher rate of fire than the standard MP5. The barrel, cocking handle and its cover were shortened and a vertical foregrip was used to replace the standard handguard. The barrel ends at the base of the foresight, which prevents the use of any sort of muzzle device.
 MP5K submachine guns are produced (by HK and under license in Iran and Turkey) in four different versions: the MP5K, MP5KA4, MP5KA1, MP5KA5, where the first two variants have adjustable, open-type iron sights (with a notched rotary drum), and the two remaining variants - fixed open sights, however the front sight post was changed and a notch was cut into the receiver top cover. The MP5K retained the capability to use optical sights through the use of an adapter.
 Ammunition:
 9x19mm FMJ 
 9x19mm BP1.

The history of the development of M1891 rifle is somewhat shady and controversial. During the official trials, two designs were selected for final - one by Russian army captain Mosin, and another, by the Belgian designer Nagant. Final design, adopted by the Commission, utilized features from both, and Leon Nagant was paid for his part, some very serious amount of money. Mosin received a rank promotion and worked on the Sestroretsk arsenal, trying to set this rifle for production. Russia's Imperial Army in 1891 adopted this rifle as the standard issue to infantry. It was used in every conflict involving Russia, & The Soviet Union, since 1891. After the 2nd World War it was replaced by the SKS, and AK-47 as the standard issue weapon. In 1930 the rifle was updated, and the production of M1891/30 pattern began. The rifle was produced in vast quantities, and is now widely used as a hunting rifle in many countries. Cheap, reliable, and simple to use, and maintain, even in harsh enviroments like The Zone. 
 Ammunition:
 standard 7.62x54 mm 7N1,
 armor-piercing 7.62x54 mm BP,
 sniper 7.62x54 mm 7N14.

The Mosin-Nagant M1891/30 scoped version. Sniper rifle, based on the M1891/30 rifles, hand-picked for accuracy, they were issued with scope mounts on the left side of the receiver, and with bolt handles bent down. Used as sniper rifles from around 1932, until the 1960's. It was then replaced by the SVD (Dragunov).
 Ammunition:
 standard 7.62x54 mm 7N1,
 armor-piercing 7.62x54 mm BP,
 sniper 7.62x54 mm 7N14.

Former and a little bit weaker first prototype version of the fn 2000 modern bullpup assault rifle, equipped with an electronic fire control module and a 40-mm grenade launcher.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 5.56x45mm SS109
 Armor-Piercing 5.56x45mm AP

Groza OC-10 is an assault rifle with an attached grenade launcher. The weapon is based on the OC-14 Groza, but chambered for the cheaper 7.62x39mm round Uses the same magazine as the AK-47, and AK-103. An ideal assault rifle for Zone conditions: compact, reliable, versatile, and powerful. A favorite among Stalkers.

 Ammunition:
 Standard 7.62x39 FMJ
 Armor-Piercing 7.62x39 AP
 VOG-25 and VOG-25P grenades
Normal 16x70 rounds. Designed for shotgun BM-16 and others shotguns. They are most effective at ranges of up to 25 meters.
16x70 cartridges. Designed for shotgun BM-16 and others shotguns. They are most effective at ranges of up to 50 meters.
16x70 slugs rounds. Normally used for hunting large animals, but they might be used for others purposes too. Designed for shotgun BM-16 and others shotguns. Effective at ranges up to 75 meters.
Blast-temperature action grenade to rifle GP-25 "Bonfire", integrated with RG-6 grenade.
Temperature (explosives) charge for the rifle grenade GP-25 "Bonfire", integrated with RG-6 grenade.

The HK G3 rifle is by many described as one of the best 7.62mm NATO battle rifles - reliable, versatile, controllable, and very popular. 
This is the civilian version, which only fires semi-auto. The rifle is fitted with a larger charging handle which makes reloading quicker. Scope, and rail are permanently attached to the rifle.
 Ammo:
7.62x51mm AP 
7.62x51mm FMJ.
7.62 Milimeter, Full Metal Jacket! \nStandard NATO round 7.62x51mm FMJ.
7.62 Milimeter, Armor Piercing round \nStandard NATO round 7.62x51mm AP.

Heckler & Koch MP5SD3, Silenced version of the famous MP5. 
This version has been modified to use the .45 ACP round, giving the gun an increased stopping power over the regular 9mm bullet.
The MP5SD3, can be fitted with a scope. 
Ammunition:
 .45 ACP 
 .45ACP Shock.
